The **2017 FA Cup Final** was the [136th](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_FA_Cup
"2016–17 FA Cup") [final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final") of the [FA
Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup"), the world's oldest football cup competition. It
took place on 27 May 2017 at [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley
Stadium") in London, England and was contested between [London
rivals](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C.%E2%80%93Chelsea_F.C._rivalry "Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea
F.C. rivalry") [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.") and
[Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C."). Arsenal won the game 2–1 to
secure a record 13th title, while manager [Arsène
Wenger](/wiki/Ars%C3%A8ne_Wenger "Arsène Wenger") became the most successful
manager in the tournament's history with seven wins.

The winners would enter the [2017–18 UEFA Europa
League](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Europa_League "2017–18 UEFA Europa League")
group stage, had they not already qualified for the [UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") via other
competitions.[3]

This was a rematch of the [2002 FA Cup Final](/wiki/2002_FA_Cup_Final "2002 FA
Cup Final") and the first final since 2003 in which both sides split the
league games against each other during the course of the season, with a 3–0
victory by Arsenal in September 2016, and a 3–1 win by Chelsea in February
2017. The game was broadcast live in the United Kingdom by both
[BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") and [BT Sport](/wiki/BT_Sport "BT Sport"). [BBC
One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One") provided the free-to-air coverage and [BT Sport
2](/wiki/BT_Sport_2 "BT Sport 2") was the pay-TV alternative.[4][5] In North
America, this was the first FA Cup Final to be televised by
[CTV](/wiki/CTV_Television_Network "CTV Television Network") in Canada and by
[FOX](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") in the United
States.

Due to the circumstances surrounding his appearance,[6] and performance on the
day,[7] Arsenal fans and former players have dubbed the game _The Mertesacker
Final_.[8]

final[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2017_FA_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=1 "Edit

### Arsenal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2017_FA_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Arsenal")]

In all results below, the score of the finalist is given first.

Round | Opposition | Score  
---|---|---  
3rd | [Preston North End](/wiki/Preston_North_End_F.C. "Preston North End F.C.") (A) | 2–1  
4th | [Southampton](/wiki/Southampton_F.C. "Southampton F.C.") (A) | 5–0  
5th | [Sutton United](/wiki/Sutton_United_F.C. "Sutton United F.C.") (A) | 2–0  
QF | [Lincoln City](/wiki/Lincoln_City_F.C. "Lincoln City F.C.") (H) | 5–0  
SF | [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C.") ([N](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium")) | 2–1 ([a.e.t.](/wiki/Overtime_\(sports\)#Association_football "Overtime \(sports\)"))  
**Key:** (H) = Home venue; (A) = Away venue; (N) = [Neutral
venue](/wiki/Neutral_venue "Neutral venue").  
  
Arsenal, as a [Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") team,
started their campaign in the third round. In it, they were drawn away at
[Football League Championship](/wiki/Football_League_Championship "Football
League Championship") [Preston North End](/wiki/Preston_North_End_F.C.
"Preston North End F.C."). At [Deepdale](/wiki/Deepdale "Deepdale"), Arsenal
won 2–1 with goals from [Aaron Ramsey](/wiki/Aaron_Ramsey "Aaron Ramsey") and
[Olivier Giroud](/wiki/Olivier_Giroud "Olivier Giroud").[9] In the Fourth
Round, Arsenal drew fellow Premier League [Southampton](/wiki/Southampton_F.C.
"Southampton F.C."). At [St Mary's Stadium](/wiki/St_Mary%27s_Stadium "St
Mary's Stadium"), Arsenal won 5–0 with two goals from [Danny
Welbeck](/wiki/Danny_Welbeck "Danny Welbeck") and a [hat-trick](/wiki/Hat-
trick "Hat-trick") from [Theo Walcott](/wiki/Theo_Walcott "Theo Walcott").[10]
In the Fifth Round, Arsenal were drawn against [non-league](/wiki/Non-
league_football "Non-league football") [National
League](/wiki/National_League_\(division\) "National League \(division\)")
[Sutton United](/wiki/Sutton_United_F.C. "Sutton United F.C.") away. At
[Gander Green Lane](/wiki/Gander_Green_Lane "Gander Green Lane"), Arsenal won
2–0 with goals from [Lucas Pérez](/wiki/Lucas_P%C3%A9rez "Lucas Pérez") and
Walcott.[11] The match was also noted for Sutton United's reserve goalkeeper
[Wayne Shaw](/wiki/Wayne_Shaw_\(footballer\) "Wayne Shaw \(footballer\)")
being investigated by [The FA](/wiki/The_FA "The FA") and [Gambling
Commission](/wiki/Gambling_Commission "Gambling Commission") for eating a pie
pitchside despite there being betting odds on him doing so.[12] In the
quarter-finals, Arsenal were drawn at home against National League [Lincoln
City](/wiki/Lincoln_City_F.C. "Lincoln City F.C."). At the [Emirates
Stadium](/wiki/Emirates_Stadium "Emirates Stadium"), Arsenal won 5–0 with
goals from Walcott, Giroud, an [own goal](/wiki/Own_goal "Own goal") by [Luke
Waterfall](/wiki/Luke_Waterfall "Luke Waterfall"), [Alexis
Sánchez](/wiki/Alexis_S%C3%A1nchez "Alexis Sánchez") and Ramsey.[13] In the
semi-final at neutral Wembley Stadium, Arsenal played against Premier League
[Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C.") and
reached the final after a 2–1 win with goals from [Nacho
Monreal](/wiki/Nacho_Monreal "Nacho Monreal") and Sánchez.[14]

Chelsea also started in the third round where they were drawn at home against
[League One](/wiki/Football_League_One "Football League One") side
[Peterborough United](/wiki/Peterborough_United_F.C. "Peterborough United
F.C."). At [Stamford Bridge](/wiki/Stamford_Bridge_\(stadium\) "Stamford
Bridge \(stadium\)"), Chelsea won 4–1 with two goals from
[Pedro](/wiki/Pedro_\(footballer,_born_July_1987\) "Pedro \(footballer, born
July 1987\)") and a goal each from [Michy Batshuayi](/wiki/Michy_Batshuayi
"Michy Batshuayi") and [Willian](/wiki/Willian_\(footballer\) "Willian
\(footballer\)") despite having club captain [John Terry](/wiki/John_Terry
"John Terry") [sent off](/wiki/Penalty_card#Red_card "Penalty card").[15] In
the fourth round, they were drawn with
[Championship](/wiki/Football_League_Championship "Football League
Championship") team [Brentford](/wiki/Brentford_F.C. "Brentford F.C.") at
home. Chelsea won 4–0 with goals from Pedro, Willian, [Branislav
Ivanović](/wiki/Branislav_Ivanovi%C4%87 "Branislav Ivanović") and
Batshuayi.[16] In the fifth round, Chelsea were drawn away against
Championship [Wolverhampton Wanderers](/wiki/Wolverhampton_Wanderers_F.C.
"Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C."). At [Molineux Stadium](/wiki/Molineux_Stadium
"Molineux Stadium"), Chelsea won 2–0 with goals from Pedro and [Diego
Costa](/wiki/Diego_Costa "Diego Costa").[17] In the Quarter-finals, they were
drawn against fellow Premier League side and [FA Cup
holders](/wiki/2016_FA_Cup_Final "2016 FA Cup Final") [Manchester
United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C."). At Stamford
Bridge, Chelsea won 1–0 thanks to a goal from [N'Golo
Kanté](/wiki/N%27Golo_Kant%C3%A9 "N'Golo Kanté").[18] In the semi-finals at
Wembley Stadium, Chelsea were drawn against fellow Premier League and [London
rivals](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C.%E2%80%93Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C._rivalry "Chelsea
F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry"), [Tottenham
Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C."). Chelsea
reached the final with a 4–2 win with two goals from Willian and a goal each
from [Eden Hazard](/wiki/Eden_Hazard "Eden Hazard") and [Nemanja
Matić](/wiki/Nemanja_Mati%C4%87 "Nemanja Matić").[19]

## Pre-match[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2017_FA_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Pre-match")]

Arsenal were appearing in the final of the FA Cup for the 20th time, the
club's third in four years. They had won the cup twelve times previously (in
[1930](/wiki/1930_FA_Cup_Final "1930 FA Cup Final"),
[1936](/wiki/1936_FA_Cup_Final "1936 FA Cup Final"),
[1950](/wiki/1950_FA_Cup_Final "1950 FA Cup Final"),
[1971](/wiki/1971_FA_Cup_Final "1971 FA Cup Final"),
[1979](/wiki/1979_FA_Cup_Final "1979 FA Cup Final"),
[1993](/wiki/1993_FA_Cup_Final "1993 FA Cup Final"),
[1998](/wiki/1998_FA_Cup_Final "1998 FA Cup Final"),
[2002](/wiki/2002_FA_Cup_Final "2002 FA Cup Final"),
[2003](/wiki/2003_FA_Cup_Final "2003 FA Cup Final"),
[2005](/wiki/2005_FA_Cup_Final "2005 FA Cup Final"),
[2014](/wiki/2014_FA_Cup_Final "2014 FA Cup Final") and
[2015](/wiki/2015_FA_Cup_Final "2015 FA Cup Final")) and were beaten in the
final seven times, most recently in [2001](/wiki/2001_FA_Cup_Final "2001 FA
Cup Final"). By comparison, Chelsea were making their 12th appearance in a FA
Cup final.[20] The club won the cup seven times
([1970](/wiki/1970_FA_Cup_Final "1970 FA Cup Final"),
[1997](/wiki/1997_FA_Cup_Final "1997 FA Cup Final"),
[2000](/wiki/2000_UEFA_Cup_Final "2000 UEFA Cup Final"),
[2007](/wiki/2007_FA_Cup_Final "2007 FA Cup Final"),
[2009](/wiki/2009_FA_Cup_Final "2009 FA Cup Final"),
[2010](/wiki/2010_FA_Cup_Final "2010 FA Cup Final") and
[2012](/wiki/2012_FA_Cup_Final "2012 FA Cup Final")) and lost four finals.
Arsenal and Chelsea had previously met 13 times in the FA Cup. Arsenal held an
advantage in those meetings, winning seven of the last eight. Chelsea,
however, won the last FA Cup tie, a 2–1 victory in April 2009.[21] This was
the second FA Cup final to feature both sides; the first was won by Arsenal in
2002.[22]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Conte_UDI-
ATA_1-3.jpg/170px-Conte_UDI-ATA_1-3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Conte_UDI-ATA_1-3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Conte_UDI-ATA_1-3.jpg "Enlarge")

Chelsea manager [Antonio Conte](/wiki/Antonio_Conte "Antonio Conte") was on
course to win the [domestic
double](/wiki/Double_\(association_football\)#England "Double \(association
football\)") in his first season at the club.

The most recent meeting between the two teams was a league encounter in
February 2017. Chelsea beat Arsenal by three goals to one, a result which
moved them 12 points clear in first position.[23] The win was significant
given Chelsea lost the reverse fixture 3–0 in September 2016, a "watershed
moment" in their season according to BBC journalist [Phil
McNulty](/wiki/Phil_McNulty "Phil McNulty").[24] While Arsenal struggled to
build momentum throughout autumn and winter, Chelsea manager [Antonio
Conte](/wiki/Antonio_Conte "Antonio Conte")'s tactical switch from
[4–3–3](/wiki/Formation_\(association_football\)#4.E2.80.933.E2.80.933
"Formation \(association football\)") to
[3–4–3](/wiki/Formation_\(association_football\)#3.E2.80.934.E2.80.933
"Formation \(association football\)") thereafter resulted in a 13-match
winning run.[25][26] They won the Premier League with two matches to
spare,[26] and later set a new divisional record for the most wins (30).[27]
Arsenal ended the season in fifth place, their lowest placing under manager
[Arsène Wenger](/wiki/Ars%C3%A8ne_Wenger "Arsène Wenger"), and missed out on
[UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League")
football for the first time in 20 years.[28] Wenger's future had been cast
into doubt following a bad run of form in February and March, which saw the
team lose 10–2 on aggregate against [Bayern Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC
Bayern Munich") in the Champions League, and four of their five league
matches.[29] To arrest the decline, Wenger adopted a similar tactical change
to Conte, playing three defenders at the back.[30] Arsenal went on to win
eight of their last nine fixtures, but Wenger admitted his team were
[outsiders](/wiki/Underdog_\(term\) "Underdog \(term\)") for the final: "This
time we are not favourites, it’s quite even or maybe Chelsea are ahead, so
it’s a bit similar to what happened in the semi-final against Manchester City.
That’s part of what makes it all exciting as well."[31] Of his future he said,
"It will not be my last match anyway, because I will stay, no matter what
happens, in football."[32]

"Mertesacker is going to be crucial for Arsenal if he plays; he will have to
play very well if Arsenal are to have any chance. If he doesn't play well then
Chelsea are going to cut through Arsenal like a knife through butter."

[Paul Merson](/wiki/Paul_Merson "Paul Merson")'s pre-match assessment[33]

Conte described Wenger as one of the greats in football, and felt he would
remain as Arsenal manager come the season's end.[34] "He has done a fantastic
job. Sometimes in England I think you undervalue the achievement of qualifying
for the Champions League. Only this season they haven't qualified for the
Champions League," he continued.[34] Conte reiterated the importance of his
players keeping their focus and wanted Chelsea to "pay great attention and
focus" to their opponents.[35] Hazard, who was playing in his first FA Cup
final, was eager to win the competition: "For Chelsea, for such a big club
like this, you need to win one, two, three trophies every season if you can.
Now we have the possibility to win another trophy so all the players are ready
for that. It's such a great competition for the fans."[34]

Chelsea and Arsenal were expected to line up in a 3–4–3 formation.[36] Whereas
the former club had no injury or suspension worries, Arsenal had doubts over
the fitness of [Petr Čech](/wiki/Petr_%C4%8Cech "Petr Čech") and [Shkodran
Mustafi](/wiki/Shkodran_Mustafi "Shkodran Mustafi"), and were already without
defenders [Laurent Koscielny](/wiki/Laurent_Koscielny "Laurent Koscielny")
(suspension) and Gabriel (ankle injury).[36] [Per
Mertesacker](/wiki/Per_Mertesacker "Per Mertesacker") was expected to start;
the [Germany international](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany
national football team") only featured once for Arsenal's first team during
the season.[37] The day before the final _[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian
"The Guardian")_ reported that Wenger chose [David Ospina](/wiki/David_Ospina
"David Ospina") to start in goal ahead of Čech.[38]

Both clubs received an allocation of approximately 28,000 tickets.[39] For
adults, these were priced £45, £65, £85 and £115, with concessions in
place.[39] Chelsea supporters were situated in the west side of the ground,
while Arsenal's were allocated in the east.[40] The remaining 14,000 tickets
were distributed to volunteers involved in the FA's work.[39] Finalists stood
to receive £900,000 minimum, the winners earned £1.8 million.[41] Security at
Wembley Stadium was tightened in the wake of the [Manchester Arena
bombing](/wiki/Manchester_Arena_bombing "Manchester Arena bombing"); as a
security measure Arsenal cancelled a screening of the game at their
ground.[42] Both clubs cancelled plans for [open top bus](/wiki/Open_top_bus
"Open top bus") victory parades.[43]

[Sol Campbell](/wiki/Sol_Campbell "Sol Campbell") and [Eddie
Newton](/wiki/Eddie_Newton "Eddie Newton") came onto the pitch to greet the
supporters and place the trophy on a plinth.[44] As they departed, the
traditional Cup Final hymn, "[Abide with Me](/wiki/Abide_with_Me "Abide with
Me")" was sung by representatives of eight clubs, including [Lincoln
City](/wiki/Lincoln_City_F.C. "Lincoln City F.C."),
[Guernsey](/wiki/Guernsey_F.C. "Guernsey F.C."),
[Millwall](/wiki/Millwall_F.C. "Millwall F.C.") and Sutton United.[45] The
teams emerged moments later led by their managers, and players were greeted by
[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge](/wiki/Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cambridge
"Prince William, Duke of Cambridge"). Soprano Emily Haig sang the national
anthem and a minute's silence was then held to honour the victims of the
Manchester attack.[44][45] Prince William, [Andy Burnham](/wiki/Andy_Burnham
"Andy Burnham"), the [Mayor of Greater
Manchester](/wiki/Mayor_of_Greater_Manchester "Mayor of Greater Manchester")
and FA chairman [Greg Clarke](/wiki/Greg_Clarke "Greg Clarke") lay wreaths on
the pitch in tribute.[44]

## Match[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2017_FA_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Match")]

### Summary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2017_FA_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Summary")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Arsenal_2_Chelsea_1_%2834621140880%29.jpg/220px-
Arsenal_2_Chelsea_1_%2834621140880%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arsenal_2_Chelsea_1_\(34621140880\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Arsenal_2_Chelsea_1_\(34621140880\).jpg "Enlarge")

Moses receiving a red card in the second half

Despite what was expected to be a tight affair, Arsenal dominated the early
proceedings and opened the scoring with a goal from [Alexis
Sánchez](/wiki/Alexis_S%C3%A1nchez "Alexis Sánchez") in the 4th minute,
shooting past the advancing goalkeeper from six yards out with his right foot.
The goal was initially flagged as
[offside](/wiki/Offside_\(association_football\) "Offside \(association
football\)") due to [Aaron Ramsey](/wiki/Aaron_Ramsey "Aaron Ramsey") being in
an offside position. After discussing with his linesman, referee Anthony
Taylor overrode the decision and awarded Arsenal the goal due to Ramsey not
attempting to play the ball.[46] Sánchez also handled the ball in the lead up
to the goal but this was not seen by the referee.[47] Arsenal then hit the
post twice from close range in the first half through Aaron Ramsey and [Danny
Welbeck](/wiki/Danny_Welbeck "Danny Welbeck").

In the second half, [Victor Moses](/wiki/Victor_Moses "Victor Moses") received
a second yellow card for diving in the penalty box in the 68th minute, leaving
Chelsea with ten men. Chelsea equalised through [Diego
Costa](/wiki/Diego_Costa "Diego Costa") in the 76th minute when he controlled
the ball on his chest in the penalty area before shooting low to the left with
his right foot. Three minutes later [Aaron Ramsey](/wiki/Aaron_Ramsey "Aaron
Ramsey") scored for Arsenal by heading in an [Olivier
Giroud](/wiki/Olivier_Giroud "Olivier Giroud") cross from the left from six
yards out.[48]
